=Getting Started with the Testboy=

This Hello World exercise introduces the process of creating a simple unit test with the Testboy. To do this exercise you need to have some familiarity with JavaScript.

==Hello Testboy==
To run Hello World example, follow the steps described below.

==Step 1: Getting the Testboy==

Download the Testboy from the Subversion repository by executing the following command from the command line:

{{{

svn checkout http://testboy.googlecode.com/svn/trunk/ testboy-read-only

}}}

==Step 2: Create a simple web page==

Create a simple web page containing a JavaScript funciton that needs to be tested.

{{{

<!DOCTYPE html>
<html>
    <head>
        <title>Hello, Testboy</title>
        <script type="text/javascript">
            function sayHi(name) {
                return "Hi, " + name;
            }
        </script>
    </head>
    <body>
    </body>
</html>

}}}

==Step 3: Create a utit test using the Testboy API==

Include the testboy.js in your web page and place the following JavaScript snippet before the closing
body tag, as it shown below.

{{{

<!DOCTYPE html>
<html>
    <head>
        <title>Hello, Testboy</title>
        <script type="text/javascript">
            function sayHi(name) {
                return "Hi, " + name;
            }
        </script>
        <script type="text/javascript" src="testboy.js"></script>
    </head>
    <body>
    
        <script type="text/javascript">
            var myTestCase = new testboy.TestCase("My Test Case");
 
            myTestCase.testSayHi = function () {
                var hiStr = sayHi("Testboy");

                assertNotNull(hiStr, "The result should not be null");
                assertNotUndefined(hiStr, "The result should not be undefined");
                assertTrue(typeof hiStr == "string", "The result should be type of string.");
            }
            
            testboy.runner.add(myTestCase);
            testboy.runner.run();
        </script>
    </body>
</html>

}}}
